narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Hylomorphism presupposed a fairly good amount of knowledge of ontology (mainly contemporary analytic), much of which I had only a cursory understanding of prior to the seminar, but I was able to pick up what I needed along the way. Primarily, I benefitted from Hylomorphism by gaining a working familiarity with (a) the problems, decision points, and desiderata hylomorphists (especially neo-Aristotelians) seek to address in their substance ontology and (b) the key players in contemporary hylomorphic theory and where they stand on key ontological doctrines.

understanding of the modern dilemmas posed to the Aristotelian hylomorphist account 
analysis internally and externally of Aristotle's model of hylomorphism
philosophy paper writing techniques 
class discussion leading, esp at a grad-school level proficiency
Developed a deeper understanding of pertinent questions in hylomorphism.
Understanding of Aristotle, hylomorphism, and graduate-level philosophy
I gained a thorough and broad understanding of the current state of contemporary hylomorphic philosophy.
The contemporary philosophical debates surrounding an ancient theory that is still valid and regaining popularity.

I developed a metaphysical framework of realitythat's something. More generally, I learned how to analyze and evaluate metaphysical claims and concepts, and became familiar with hylomorphism. But besides all that, I felt like the papers I was writing at the end of the class were some of the best I have ever written, largely thanks to this class.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: 
broad and foundational selection of texts with helpful supplemental readings
narrow scope of enquiry to establish truths and discern critical areas of disagreement 
SPECTACULAR guest lectures from nearly all the modern thinkers encountered in the syllabus 

Weaknesses:
a little too much fluidity in the syllabus -> lack of clarity on specifics of assignments in written form
The class featured several guest lecturers who were helpful.
Very strong
A focus on Aristotle himself for two or three weeks at the beginning of the course would have proven helpful I think, especially before progressing onto difficult scholarly papers on his theories.

I loved the seminars and the fact that Prof. Charles brought in philosophers from universities all over the world to talk about their papers. I also thought that the system of having people present on a paper was good, as well as the system of having people send in questions before class. It made me actually think about what I read. Also, Prof. Charles' comments on papers when he returned them were fantastic. My only complaint is that the seminar discussions sometimes went down a specialized rabbit hole.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Guest lectures - Professor Charles should be the perfect example for utilizing academic connections and resources to expand class engagement during the restricted seminar format. I was overwhelmingly impressed by David's commitment to engaging students with the highest calibre thinkers in the hylomorphist debate currently, and it was easily my most favorite class as a result.
The live online lectures worked without issue all semester.

David Charles brought in four or five academics working in contemporary hylomorphism, which gave us and opportunity to read their work, and then ask questions and offer critiques in class. This would not have been possible if not for the digital format, and I enjoyed it immensely, and also heard it was helpful for the other students and even the academics themselves as well!
Like I said, the practice of bringing in people from all over the world to discuss their papers was fantastic. The course really did well in the virtual environment.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I would highly recommend this class to students interested in any form of Aristotelian philosophy. Every class I've taken with David has been phenomenal, and his influence was the reason for choosing philosophy as my major. 
Given that it's a higher level philosophy course, I'd recommend taking the course only if students have engaged Aristotle deeply and in a philosophical context. Moreover, a dedicated interest and background in philosophy is helpful and necessary to actualize the course from its full potentiality.
Yes, this was a great seminar for philosophy majors who are interested in exploring hylomorphism in great detail.
Only to Aristotle or metaphysics geeks

Yes; if you want to know what it's like to be a graduate student in philosophy, you should take a course like this with David. He will hold you to the expectations of a graduate student and you will get the opportunity to do real academic work.
Yes, if a philosophy major wishes to have a solid foundation in metaphysics.

I would highly recommend this course. Hylomorphism is a fascinating topic, and now I am convinced that it is not only an up-and-coming area in philosophy, but also true. It's an interesting philosophy course that teaches you a lot.
